4680a653635eba9c5573826ac7546e16.title: Netflix, Amazon, and the End of Independent Film As We Know It

8572ae8e36ecfe45f99bc76d1bfe9f24.title: Netflix, Amazon, and the End of Independent Film As We Know It

81d40853f2bfc338aa427bea837cfe72.title: Netflix, Amazon, and the End of Independent Film As We Know It

paragraphs.name: aef4
paragraphs.text: In recent years, many of the indie-boutique shingles that the major studios once supported — Paramount Vantage, Warner Independent Pictures — have closed up shop. They’ve become victims of an increasingly corporatized, IP-centric major studio strategy. Those that remain, including Fox Searchlight, Miramax, and Focus Features, have been weakened. These satellite operations working inside corporations supported independent filmmakers and smaller projects, in an effort to serve arthouse audiences, court award season prestige, and provide the corporations a bit of soul. The continued dissolution of these outlets has created an open lane. In their place, a new breed of independent-minded curators — based largely in Silicon Valley and Seattle — has risen. The tension between them starts in theaters and ends at home.

paragraphs.name: 631d
paragraphs.text: “There’s no physical supply chain,” Sarandos told Deadline. “So the idea that you could do something on a global platform was impossible then and more than possible right now — and the norm. Netflix now, we’re in every country in the world except for Syria, North Korea and China. When we launch our movies and TV shows, we launch them everywhere at the same second. When we buy a movie at Sundance, it’s available to the whole world.”

521233c71f0c.title: Good grief. This was an amazing piece. Thanks Sean!

paragraphs.name: 6c31
paragraphs.text: Good grief. This was an amazing piece. Thanks Sean!

6b02166b5cf.title: Thumbs up on a very informative article.

paragraphs.name: 99d5
paragraphs.text: Thumbs up on a very informative article. Besides the big tent pole movies on opening weeks, every other movie I have seen in theaters is a ghost town. The theater model is on life support and kept alive by the hardcore fans and the occasional blockbuster. Will the theaters even be around in 10 years?

1d9220bd8ec5.title: I see a world where Amazon and Netflix would want to fund some of these more creative independent…

paragraphs.name: fcba
paragraphs.text: I see a world where Amazon and Netflix would want to fund some of these more creative independent projects — they have less risk because of gobs of cash, and the benefit of producing quality content and being a critically acclaimed producer far outweigh a few misses.

33ee6b551910.title: Thanks Sean for this very interesting, well-written piece.

paragraphs.text: Thanks Sean for this very interesting, well-written piece. It surely looks like a work of weeks, if not months!

paragraphs.name: 57d6
paragraphs.text: I’m very fascinated by the different approaches towards theaters chosen by Amazon and Netflix respectively. It appears to me as if Netflix seems driven to upend/disrupt the status-quo in a more radical fashion…

d36f2056e81f.title: Warner Independent, Paramount Vantage all went into the dust years ago.

paragraphs.name: 10ec
paragraphs.text: Warner Independent, Paramount Vantage all went into the dust years ago. But hard to tell this story without figuring out how a24 fits into the equation. There’s unexpected juice in the theatrical market for distributors willing to nurture it. And that can be anyone from Amazon on down.

dff55271616e.title: I’ll be sad to lose the movie theater experience but, let’s face it, for people who want to spend…

paragraphs.name: 37c0
paragraphs.text: I’ll be sad to lose the movie theater experience but, let’s face it, for people who want to spend their $10/ticket on a film worth watching, there’s a very short season each year — when Oscar picks come out and some small art films come through town. We have an 18-plex and it’s full of children’s films or blockbuster garbage 10 months out of the year…

4f6b9358e19.title: I think quality cable network tv surpassed movies a long time ago anyway.

paragraphs.name: 3e9d
paragraphs.text: I think quality cable network tv surpassed movies a long time ago anyway. I look forward to new seasons of shows and new show premiers a lot more than movie releases.

8b7a93589939.title: Parker’s Screening Room idea is laughably bad.

paragraphs.text: Parker’s Screening Room idea is laughably bad. Sure, that model makes money when some upper-crust couple decides they’d rather stay in for Woody Allen’s latest instead of traversing all the way to the cinemas. But at that low a price point — which dropped heavily since its debut and is NOT helping their case — the average family of 4 now gets to save…

fa679ed0545f.title: This is for me the main advantage Netflix still hold over Amazon.

paragraphs.name: 77bb
paragraphs.text: This is for me the main advantage Netflix still hold over Amazon. If you do a lot of traveling or live outside the US Amazon can be really frustrating, though at the end of the day both are producing great content and I’m grateful for that.

paragraphs.name: 05db
paragraphs.text: Also, fantastic article 👏👏

As a filmmaker I’m conflicted. Netflix is a smart platform to distribute an ultra low-budget film if possible. I can personally attest to having friends tell me of obscure movies I’d never heard of that had become a popular Netflix watch. Also, a lot of would be great indie-filmmakers have taken their talents to TV and that’s also I think smart. TV…

d596c278da29.title: Netflix and Amazon will certainly turn into a studio system of their own, it’s human nature.

paragraphs.text: Netflix and Amazon will certainly turn into a studio system of their own, it’s human nature. OTOH, there is a future where we just have abundant content, because it’s so much easier and cheaper than it used to be. If robots do all the work, there is the potential for great creativity, though I doubt the human race can see it through to that good endpoint.

81fe0a713c98.title: You captured a lot of important elements impacting the indie film scene, but the newer indie…

paragraphs.name: a3ef
paragraphs.text: You captured a lot of important elements impacting the indie film scene, but the newer indie distributors on the scene are not even mentioned here. Given the impact that A24 has had in the past couple of years (& oscars won — Best Pic this year, Best Doc last year) it’s a glaring miss to not mention that company and the way that it’s championing new…

paragraphs.name: 15ca
paragraphs.text: Great piece of writing Sean.

paragraphs.name: 6df3
paragraphs.text: Amazing article. I agree with some of the comments below about how I would’ve loved something about smaller, popular studios like A24 or Annapurna, but great nonetheless.

paragraphs.name: 7c1b
paragraphs.text: Fennessey, this is fantastic work. I hope you continue to take periodic breaks from your editorial work and keep bringing deep dives into worlds that most of us don’t have access to. My work is tangentially related to the subject here so I may have more interest than some; but this article is fascinating and juxtaposes the hard choices that stakeholders at each end will have to make in the near and long term.

3df2e1522b83.title: Actually, though I may be wrong, I don’t think either Vantage or Warner Independent ever got much…

paragraphs.name: 9cde
paragraphs.text: Actually, though I may be wrong, I don’t think either Vantage or Warner Independent ever got much traction. The strongest of these studio-financed indies were always Fox Searchlight, Sony Classics and Focus.
